It's a common misconception that the Higgs boson is what gives other particles mass, but it is not the particle it's the Higgs field that give particles their mass. Some particles, including the Higgs Boson, interact with the field more strongly then others which is why some are massive and others are massless.

This is why the discovery of a possible Higgs boson is so exciting.  Physicists come up with hypotheses to explain what we see, test them to develop theories, and then continue testing those theories to plug in the holes.  If there is no Higgs boson, that means we need to rethink the Standard Model.  Likewise, we hope that studying this new boson will help fill in some more of the holes (like gravity, for instance), or at least point us in the right direction.
